book.materiality_desc: Textured navy blue cover with burgundy cloth corners and a burgundy cloth spine binding. There are no images on the cover. The spine shows slight signs of wear. Inside the pages are unruled and show various patterned discolourations that indicate the book may have held photographs or clippings in a different arrangement before Morgan decided upon the current layout.

pages.notes: Morgan's signature, Scrapbook 12, Date Range, Page Range written in gold ink on black paper, the latter page number in the range written in blue ink on white paper, self portrait
pages.desc: A collaged cover page for Scrapbook 12, which includes Morgan's signature, the page range, and the years during which the book's material was collected. Under the year range, Morgan has pasted in a clipping that reads "Great pains have been taken to illustrate the book adequately". A black and white photograph of a mushroom cloud is pasted at the top of the page, and in the right hand corner of this image, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of a man from the neck up who is wearing something white on his head. In the right hand corner of the photograph of the man, Morgan has pasted a very small original photographic self-portrait taken in a mirror. The page also includes a colour clipping from Decamps' "The Villa Doria Pamphili, Rome", a black and white photograph of a television set, which has been pasted onto a black and white photograph showing the side of a stone building, a colour photograph of a man in a blue work uniform seated in front of a piece of machinery, a colour photograph of a Russian sign, a paragraph of text stating that "The reader must be aware that there exist an infinity of universes co-present in space but differing in time (paratime) and another infinity of universes co-present in time but in different dimensions of space (hyperspace), in which all potential causal chains permissible under the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle are in fact realised", and a small black and white photograph of a man walking on what appears to be a beach. Also included is a black and white photograph of light filtering through pine tree branches. In the lower left corner of the pine tree photograph, Morgan has pasted a small black and white photograph of a shirtless man from the waist up who is holding up a fishing net.

A continuation of the collaged cover page for Scrapbook 12. Along the top of the page, Morgan has pasted in three sections of text, reading "The Image of Here and Now - ", "Defence of the Ephemeral", "don't let me put anybody off. It at least has curiosity value." Below this is a large colour photograph of an industrial plant at night. Three images have been pasted on to the plant photograph: on the right hand edge of the plant clipping is a black and white photograph of a large metal pipe, along the bottom edge of the plant clipping is a black and white photograph of a Russian sign over a doorway, on the left hand corner of the plant clipping is a colour photograph of a camera lens. On the camera lens clipping, Morgan has pasted a photographic self portrait taken in a mirror, in which he is wearing a kilt, and a blue piece of paper with black typeface that reads "Forteana". Also included on the page is a white paper clipping that reads "'The White-Haired Girl" and a second newspaper clipping that reads "Wörther See". These latter two clippings are pasted onto a black and white photograph of a pack of cigarettes leaning against a mirror in which you can see the cigarette package reflected. The package reads "l'Océan glacial / jeune fille aux yeux bleus" and "étaient déjà blancs". The cigarette package is pasted onto a large colour photograph of five men sitting on a mountain top looking at the green vista around them. Along the top of this colour photograph are more clippings, which overlap onto the colour clipping, including a colour text-based clipping showing Russian text, onto which Morgan has pasted the phrase "Curiositez Inouyes", a colour photograph showing a young boy from the back as he is pulling a large book from a shelf, a distorted black and white photograph of a young boy in a school uniform, and a colour image that is difficult to make out, but that seems to show water. Morgan has also included a black and white photograph of pillars in a ruin, and in the lower right corner of this clipping, he has pasted a black and white photograph of a young man outside squatting down and possibly feeding a small animal.

pages.notes: pink and blue ink doodle, self portrait
pages.desc: This page features a black and white photograph of a young boy taken by Bernard Poinssot, onto which Morgan has pasted a small black and white photograph of a stone carving onto the upper right hand corner. This page also includes a handwritten line from Chaucer, reading "YOUR YËN TWO WOL SLEE ME SODENLY", a black and white photograph of an ornate turtle clock, a separately clipped caption describing the turtle clock , which states that the turtle "floats in the basin", "attached to nothing mechanical", and no matter where it is placed, it "swims straight for the figure on the rim of the basin which indicates the correct time". The clipping explains that "a concealed magnet" moves with the clock and so directs the turtle's movements. Below this clipping is a black and white photograph of a young man sitting on a hillside, a black and white photographic self portrait of Morgan taken in a mirror, two colour decorative clippings of jewels and stones, a black and white reproduction of Matsys and Patinir's "St. Christopher", a black and white photograph that appears to show a television screen in the dark, an original photograph of a man and woman at a table (the woman is holding something up to her face and the man is holding what appears to be a piece of paper in his hand), and a large colour photograph of pink, purple, and striped petunias. Also included is a paragraph of prose by Genet, discussing "a universe of the irremediable", wherein "instead of acting and knowing we are acting, we know we are acted upon", a clipping describing a 14-year-old boy in Washington who is reported to have decided to avoid turning in false fire alarms by actually setting a fire before turning in the alarm, and a large handwritten clipping in a cyrallic alphabet.

This page features a large colour photograph of the National Autonomous University of Mexico, showing the library building across a lake, as well as a colour photograph of a University of Mexico sciences building, and a black and white photograph of a mural by Morado on a science building of "Mexico's new University City". The page also includes a black and white photograph of a boy wearing a helmet with something, possibly food, protruding from his mouth, a black and white photograph of what appears to be ice, an black and white photograph of a young man in uniform sitting on some steps, which Morgan has captioned "Italy c. 1860', a black and white photograph of a poster, which itself displays four photographs of men working with machines, a red and a green stamp from Mexico, the green costing 15 cts and the red costing 30 cts, and a black and white photograph of a beach with several people walking on it. Text-based clippings on the page include a caption for the colour photograph of the University of Mexico science building, a short clipping reporting on a Russian man named Egor Koroev who celebrated his 155th birthday, a small clipping stating that a new cathedral able to accommodate 15,000 people was opened in Stalingrad, making it the "largest cathedral constructed in the past 500 years". The cathedral is also said to contain the "third largest organ in the world". A 1954 article reports on atomic research being conducted by Dr. Yagoda. The research focuses on "an atomic particle which seems to have been blown out of an atomic bomb in American or Russia and transferred to a photographic plate in Britain after passing through the inside of a cow in India" and is titled "Atomic Particle's Travels".

This page features two large black and white photographs, one of a carved stone head and one of cloudy skies above sand hills. On the photograph of the sandy hills, Morgan has added in two collage elements: a black and white photograph of an animal's eye pasted onto the sky and a black and white photograph of a long horn extending from the upper right corner of the hill photograph. Between the two large clippings, Morgan has pasted a text-based clipping that reads "'Thought end of world had come'" and a black and white photograph of a mountain surrounded by clouds or dust.

The top of this page features two black and white photographs from newspapers that depict Hydrogen Bombs exploding. The larger of the two pictures includes a caption that reads "Like a crouching, terrible monster - a Horror-Bomb at the moment of explosion in the Pacific-a searing, burning, blinding ball of fire which measured more than three miles across. And this picture was taken from FIFTY MILES AWAY." The smaller photograph includes a caption that reads "The Bomb Behind the Debate . . . This was the world's first H-bomb blast". The page also includes a small 1954 text-based clipping titled "This is the Hydrogen Bomb", and it reads "When it was exploded in the Marshall Islands in the autumn of 1952 a whole island - Elugelab, in the Eniwetok group - disappeared. It sent up a fireball three-and-a-quarter miles in diameter to a height of 12,000 feet. The first pictures of this massive explosion were released today." The bottom of the page features a large colour photograph of the Armour Labratories building, captioned as "Pharmaceutical Center in Kankakee, Ill., Designed by Holabird, Root, and Burgee, makes Gamma Globulin, vitamin B-12. At right is water tower. Morgan has also added the date 1953 to the clipping. Pasted on to this clipping are two collage elements. In the upper left corner of the clipping, Morgan has included a black and white photograph of a man in a top hat looking through a magnifying glass, and in the bottom right corner of the clipping, he has pasted in a black and white photograph of a young man dressed in a plaid shirt with a collar and a jacket.

This page includes a series of several large black and white photographs of the H-Bomb explosions published in Newsweek in 1954 and captioned as "Between Yesterday and Doomsday", as well as a brief write-up contextualizing the photographs. The write-up states that the H-Bomb "was over 100 times more powerful than the A-Bomb set off in the Marshall Islands the year before, and 250 times more powerful than the A-bomb that killed some 80,000 human beings in Hiroshima, Aug. 5, 1945, and leveled an area larger than that of Newport News, Va.". This page also features a colour photograph of a young boy wearing a white necklace, a small line of text that reads "Some coffins nowadays are proof against nuclear radiation", the full text of Muir's "The Grave of Prometheus", a black and white photograph of three men standing in a fairly barren landscape, a black and white photograph of a man who is turned away from the camera and is pointing up into the sky, a stylized colour photograph of several people in various colourful costumes, a 1957 text clipping stating that five and a half million wasps have been donated by Dr. Kinsey to the American Museum of Natural History, a black and white cropped photograph of the sea, and a short text-based clipping that reads "'Great care must always be exercised on tethering horses to trees, as they are apt to bark, and thereby destroy the trees.' - Army Order". In the bottom right corner of the page, Morgan has included a black and white photograph of a sculpture of a rider on horseback. Next to this clipping Morgan has included a newspaper clipping that reads "Confidence in Atom Bomb: Jockey's Good Prospects" and a small clipping that reads "'Shoeshine!' 'Haba-haba! Panpan!".

This page features a large colour version of the photograph of the Hydrogen Bomb. In the bottom right corner of the photograph, Morgan has pasted a small black and white photograph of a man in shadow, turned away from the camera with his head down. Also on this page is a black and white photograph of Richard Wilbur, a black and white photograph of a young man paddling a canoe solo, a black and white photograph of a young man standing in front of a car that he appears to be working on, a black and white photograph of a sculpture captioned as the "Head of St. Fortunade 15th Century", a black and white photograph of a young woman, on which Morgan has written the initials "B.D" (Bette Davis?), a black and white reproduction of a drawing of a squat man captioned as "The Town-Mayor in The Inspector-General (a drawing by Alexander Pushkin)", a black and white reproduction of a painting showing a waterside scene, which shows two bridges and several people who are variously walking and sitting, and a Paton comic that shows two stereotypically caricatured tribal men in a canoe paddling towards a mushroom cloud, with the caption "We must be approaching civilisation". The page also includes two text-based clippings, one an advertisement for an $8.50 traveller's holster, claimed to have been originally built "for diplomatic couriers" to "hold papers and cash safely under the arm", the other an advertisement for a $12.95 maroon plastic escort alarm, which sets off a "loud and long" siren at the touch of a button. The bottom of the page displays a black and white photograph of a mushroom cloud captioned as "The mushroom spreads 100 miles wide and spirals 25 miles high. At the foot of the picture is the earth's curve".

This page features a long article detailing charges laid against Lord Montagu of Beaulieu for "committing a serious offence" with John Reynolds, as well as those laid against Peter Wildeblood who was charged for "committing a serious offence" with Edward McNally, and Michael Pitt-Rivers, who was also charged. These serious offences refer to homosexual acts. Above the clipping, Morgan has included three clippings, which read "Montagu's Harrier", "A Letter From", "The Maelstrom". The page displays a photograph of each of Montagu and Wildeblood. Also on this page is a 1955 clipping stating that Dr. Evans "has conquered mount Kanchenjunga", a black and white photograph of Prokofiev, a black and white photograph of a fox running on snow with trees in the background, a small black and white photograph of a man from the waist up as he swings a golf club, an original black and white photograph of a young man with no shirt posing on a small pillar, a black and white comic self-portrait by Nadar, a black and white photograph of two coin faces captioned as "Eagles ripping pregnant hare; Agrigentum Coin (413-406 B.C.)", and a black and white photograph of men leading three donkeys that are pulling a bull behind them in an arena (probably after a bull fight). Other clippings include a Latin language clipping from Juvenal, a short clipping stating that "The Hutterites, those religious who swarm in the Dakotas, Montana, and in Alberta, Manitoba, and Saskatchewan, Canada, have the highest birth-rate in the world" and speculates that, although Hutterites are "not permitted to marry until they are 20 years old", "If the teen-agers were allowed to get together, the Hutterites would reach the -theoretical- maximum of human fertility". A 1955 clipping titled "B.I.S. takes you there" states that "a lady" has approached Mr. Mekie for insurance, as she has "booked a berth with the British Interplanetary Society for the first tourist flight to the moon". The article states that "She was quoted normal rates for flying, plus fifty per cent., but with the cautious rider: 'Non return is no proof of death.'".

The top of this page shows a black and white photograph of a dead whale in a harbor, captioned as "A ninety-foot Blue whale on the flensing platform at Grytviken", to which Morgan has added the notation "South Georgia". Next to this is an excerpted colour clipping of a leopard from a photograph of the "Lady and the Unicorn" tapestry. Below this are two Russian language clippings, a black and white photograph of three shirtless men fishing in a river, a small black and white photographic self-portrait of Morgan taken in a mirror, a black and white photograph of a baby parrot, a large colour photograph of a golden, jeweled egg and other assorted ornate knick-knacks, and a large colour photograph of an insect, with a captioned that reads "This insect looks like a crocodile, but in fact is a harmless cricket, and its eyes and teeth are a sham".

A large article on the Lord Montagu, Peter Wildeblood, and Michael Pitt-Rivers court case, detailing the evidence being given on the 19 charges being brought against the men for homosexual acts. At the end of the article, Morgan has pasted an original colour photograph of a naked man who is seated and holding a straw hat over his pelvis. Other clippings on the page include a large colour photograph of a puppet theatre decorated as a castle, as well as two puppets who are both wearing crowns, a black and white photograph of an organ, captioned as the "Festival Hall Organ", Laski's poem "Apology for My TV", a short clipping quoting Dr. Cook, who states that "the sparkling advertising signs and streetlamps of London make starlings more mature sexually than starlings living in the country", and a short clipping that reads "Electricals showed some hesitancy, and Radio shares were down, notably Radio Rentals, while, shrdl n shrdl n- --".

The bottom of this page features a large colour reproduction of a silk design depicting mountains, trees and a village. The image is captioned as "Li Po Feasting in the Peach and Pear Orchard on a Spring Night. Based on a literary piece dealing with the same subject by Li Po (701-762 A.D.), the great poet of the Tang dynasty, this silk design pictures the gaiety of the feast. Made in the Chien Lung Period (1736-1795 A.D.) of the Ching dynasty. Size: 135.8 by 70.8 centimetres". Next to this caption, Morgan has pasted a small original photograph of a naked man who is seated and hugging his knees to his chest with his head down. Above this clipping, Morgan has included two paragraphs discussing silk-weaving. Other clippings on the page include a black and white cropped photograph of a man's forehead and hair, a colour photograph of two men riding black horses in the ocean, a black and white photograph of a person riding a horse on a bridge, a small text-based clipping titled "Boy Victim of 1945 A-Blast?", which discusses Masao Kagawa, who survived Hiroshima but later died of leukemia, two Chinese postage stamps, and an article titled "'Safety' Glass", which describes the phenomena of windshields and other glass breaking as if shot, although no bullets or other damage is ever found. The article speculates that the substances used to treat and toughen safety glass may be interacting with the vapours and radio-activity being introduced to the air by "the Bomb Boys".

A large article details the continuing trial of Lord Montagu, Peter Wildeblood, and Michael-Pitt Rivers, focusing primarily on the testimony of John Reynolds and describing "the all-male party of about 10 persons at Lord Montagu's beach hut". Other clippings on the page include a short clipping stating that Dylan Thomas's poetry and Graham Greene's book are being published in the "Soviet literary journal Inostrannaya", a colour photograph of a flower, an original black and white photograph of an older man and woman seated at a set table (which Patterson notes in her spreadsheet for Digitising the Edwin Morgan Scrapbooks project may be Morgan's parents), a black and white photograph of a man in a posing pouch smiling and seated on a staircase, an original photograph of a sea-side town, a brief write up and two black and white photographs showing new airtight suits that workers in atomic plants can use to enter contaminated rooms, a photograph of Epstein's sculpture of T.S. Eliot, a 1955 photograph of Andy Stewart, a photograph of a carved sculptural figure that Morgan has annotated as being from "B. Congo", a black and white photograph of a shirtless man on a sandy beach standing in front of a surf board, and a 1761 clipping that describes the discovery of a coffin by miners in Cornwall. The article states that the body inside the coffin was of a "gigantic size" and that the coffin had a depth of "eleven feet three inches, and depth three feet, nine inches". Although the article says that the body "mouldered into dust" almost immediately, a tooth is said to have survived, measuring "two inches and a half long".

This page features a series of five photographs from the explosion of the Hydrogen Bomb. Other clippings on the page include an article about Australian fans and how they respond to celebrities, with focus on responses to Norman Lindsay and Johnny Ray, a black and white reproduction of a sketch captioned as "Boris Godunov. A drawing by Chaliapin", a black and white photograph of Utrillo and Valore, as well as a brief write-up on Utrillo's life, and a colour photograph of a fighter plane.

This page includes clippings from a report on the trials of Lord Montagu and Peter Wildeblood. The clippings detail some of the statements in court, including questions asked about letters written between Wildeblood and McNally, and a question directed at Wildeblood quoted as being "How long have you known you were an invert". Wildeblood is also quoted as saying that his relationship with McNally was based on the fact that he "needed terribly badly to have some kind of affectionate relationship with somebody else". Lord Montagu is reported as denying that he had sexual relations with Reynolds. Other clippings on this page include a black and white photograph of two men working under a shiny new car, a black and white photograph of two people's heads as one person bends down and towards the other, who appears to be a young boy one, a black and white photograph of a man with dwarfism who is leaning on a box behind him and looking away from the camera, a black and white photograph of a shirtless man wearing a cowboy hat, jeans, and cowboy boots who is posing next to a dog, a black and white photograph of two men wearing shirts, ties, and kilts, a colour photograph captioned as "Samye Dzong Monastery on the northern bank of the Yalutsangpo River. The Tibetan people's gift in architecture is shown in the building of monasteries", a black and white photograph of a building that Morgan has annotated as "Hamburgh - postwar, Administrative block, 1954", a black and white photograph of a woman with long, crimped hair who is reading a book, a colour photograph of a man leaning over a large control panel, a short clipping reporting that "the first rose with stripes ever to be shown at Melbourne, Australia, is called 'Modern Times'. The rose is red with white stripes. An official said - 'It just grew.'", and a short clipping titled "Idea for Hikers" describes a "solid inch-thick brick of compressed tea-dust...which was made in Hankow for export to Soviet Russia". The clipping includes a photograph of the brick and translates the stamp on the brick as reading "pure last year's tea". Morgan has crossed out "last year's tea", however, and written his translation of "Ceylon".

Continuing the photo series from page 2252, this page features 5 more photographs of the Hydrogen Bomb exploding. Other clippings on the page include a black and white photograph of a man in tribal dress, a sign reading "No Smoking in Groups - Smog Control Board", a black and white photograph of a strange doll seated on the arm of a chair and held in place by a man's arm (the rest of the man is not visible in this clipping), a colour drawing of a parrot, a black and white close up photograph of a human eye, a black and white photograph of a cat and an owl on top of some drawers, captioned as "The Owl and the Pussycat", and a short clipping stating that a man has been arrested for impersonating Christ under a Connecticut law "prohibiting the impersonation of a deity". However, the article asks "who is competent to pass on a question so knotty" and suggests that, "For all Judge Ginsberg knows, he has God locked up".

A large colour photograph of a female Balinese dancer in costume from the cover of Réalitiés magazine takes up the top portion of this page. In the bottom left corner of the clipping, Morgan has written "Bali". Below this large clipping, Morgan has pasted in a short article with the headline "I have just eaten 20,000,000 chlorella, writes a 'Journal' reporter. These are microscopic algae (plant life) that may be an answer to world food problems". The article focuses on the research of Dr. Fogg in London on the ways in which a nutrient-rich algae can be used for food purposes. Other clippings on this page include a black and white photograph of a man in a posing pouch leaning his torso and arms against a pillar, a colour photograph of a television set, and on the screen area of which Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of a person with arms outstretched wearing a silver mask, a colour photograph showing a fishing net in the foreground and a man walking in the background, a sketch drawing of Rimbaud captioned as "Rimbaud a few days before his death: a drawing by Isabelle Rimbaud", a colour photograph of several boys swimming in a pool with a large mountain in the background, and a black and white photograph of a boy standing outside.

Continuing the photo series from pages 2252 and 2254, there are two black and white photographs of the H-Bomb explosion at the top of the page. Below this, Morgan has included a black and white clipping showing three panels from an engraving, which depicts riders on horses carrying various instruments, a black and white photograph of a nude man who is seated in a reclining position, supporting himself by leaning on his hands, a photograph of designer Perugia's new Picasso shoe, as well as a short write-up on the shoe, an original black and white photograph of a young woman seated at a table, a black and white photograph that is difficult to make out (Patterson notes in her spreadsheet for the Digitising the Edwin Morgan Scrapbooks project that the photograph may be of a person wearing a headdress that covers their face), an original black and white photograph of a naked man who is squatting down with one arm extending in front of him, and a colour photograph from Réalitiés magazine of Balinese dancers in a group in front of a temple. Morgan has also included a sepia postcard photograph of a bridge taken through the branches of a tree with the caption "24400. Pitlochry, New Clunie Bridge. Judges' Ltd." and a black and white photograph of the Great Pyramid in Egypt, with the caption "55. The construction of the Great Pyramid: each block of stone in the artificial mountain weighs about 2 1/2 tons".

This page features a large colour photograph of two Balinese dancers from Réalitiés magazine. Beside the clipping on the right hand side, Morgan has written "Bali". Also included on the page is the full text of Madge's "The Vanishing Ballad", an original headshot photograph of a shirtless young man, a black and white photograph of a man who is looking down and away from the camera, a black and white photograph of a terrier dog, and a 1954 black and white photograph of people working in a field next to a large machine, captioned as "Kazakh SSR. Electrical winnowing of this year's wheat in the Kalaida Kolkhoz, Kustanai Region."

Continuing the photo series from pages 2252, 2254, and 2256, this page includes four black and white photographs depicting a Hydrogen Bomb exploding. Also included on this page is an excerpt from an article titled "Mexican Promoters Revive a Medieval Pastime", which described a fight between a bull and a lion in Mexico City. Although the lion ripped the bull's tongue out, the bull managed to gut the lion with his horns. The article calls the event a "barbaric stomach-turning spectacle" and notes that the bull was rewarded for his victory by being "dispatched at a local slaughterhouse and sold in the meat markets". Below the article, Morgan has included a black and white photograph of the bull standing over the dead lion, which has been taken through metal bars. The photo is captioned as "End of the Action, after a savage five-minute battle in the 15-foot-square cage, comes as the mutilated bull stands panting and bleeding over his fallen adversary. This was upset victory, for lions usually triumph over bulls". The page also includes a black and white zoomed in photograph of an animal's eye, a small black and white photograph of a kangaroo, a colour photograph of jewels and stones, a black and white photograph of a puppy leaning against a wooden frame (possibly a chair), an original black and white photograph of an empty room with two large arched windows, a black and white photographic head shot of a young man, an original colour photograph of a shirtless man seated on a short pillar with his back to the camera, and a black and white photograph of two boats and three men travelling down a river.

This page features an article titled "Montagu Case Verdicts Likely Today", detailing the recent developments in the trials of Lord Montagu, Peter Wildeblood, and Michel Pitt-Rivers. After recounting the advice given to the jury by the judge, the article clipping concludes with a statement given by Hylton-Foster, which asks "Is it likely that a man would import as the victim of his vice on his premises a creature he had never seen or heard about? It is now said that, because on a sunshiny holiday with chaps in bathing clothes in a beach hut they call one another by their Christian names, therefore it is the badge of some indecent association. Did ever snobbery put forward a more greasy exterior than that by the prosecution in this case?". Beside this clipping, Morgan has included five clippings from a Max cartoon, showing the character sweating in the sun, filling a hose with water, wrapping himself with the hose, and laying down on shaded chair to cool off. Also included on the page is a colour photograph of two men who appear to be crouching down near a dead animal, a colour photograph of flowers that Morgan has annotated as "Algerian Iris & Mimosa", a black and white photograph of a cat, a short clipping stating that a New York hotel installed a radio transmitter to communicate with their serving staff, but that the frequency intersected with a teetotal guest's hearing aid, who "left in a panic after a period of hearing a ghostly Big Brother ordering him to rush Martinis and whisky all over the hotel", an original black and white photograph of a naked man with a towel tied around his waist, a black and white photograph of a man whose arm is raised and bent at the elbow above his head, a black and white photograph of two men hiding in a large urn, and a black and white photograph of guitar player with amputated legs and metal artificial limbs standing in the street.

This page represents a more unified theme than many other pages. It focuses on the fear and the potential destruction surrounding the Cold War and its weapons, especially the Hydrogen Bomb. There are several black and white photographs of desert rock formations, including one original black and white photograph, as well as photographs of ruined buildings. Morgan has also included a black and white photograph of sand dunes, onto which Morgan has pasted a sign that reads "U.S. Atomic Energy Commission Savannah River Operations Office CONTRABAND Cameras, Film, Bombs, Incendiaries, Field Glasses, Binoculars, Electronic Sending & Receiving Devices, Dangerous Weapons, Alcoholic Beverages, Firearms, Explosives, Codes & Ciphers WARNING Persons having such unauthorized items in their possession are subject to such penalties as may be provided for by law, dismissal or other administrative action". Other images on the page include a black and white photograph of a person wearing a white hood over their face with eye-holes cut into it, a black and white photograph of stone walls in a desert landscape, onto the bottom left corner of which Morgan has pasted a clipping that reads "The only Hotel in Town with highly Radioactive Baths rich in Carbonic Acid", a black and white photograph of a desert scene and various pieces of wood, including three that are standing, captioned as "A Door-post still Standing in situ", a black and white photograph of a man lying down with his head resting on his arm, a black and white original photographic self portrait of Morgan taken in a mirror, a black and white photograph of a man outside squatting down on the ground and holding something in his hand, a black and white photograph of a cat in a shuttered window, a black and white photograph of sand dunes with a figure standing on top of one, and a black and white photograph of three men on a sand dune, two of them kneeling down and one of them standing and pointing to the right. Onto the bottom right corner of this last clipping, Morgan has pasted a clipping dated March 1959 that reads "If you want to frighten us, all right - we are frightened. But don't go on frightening us" and is attributed to Khrushchev. Other text-based clippings on this page include an article titled "Cobalt Bomb Can End Mankind", which discusses Buckthough's written warning to the United Nations that "a hydrogen bomb explosion could pollute the air with radioactivity lasting for several thousands of years", a clipping that states that "military leaders are convinced the bomb [Hydrogen bomb] is our best bargaining weapon" and that they "don't want their hands tied", a clipping of a sign that declares "This Planet was discovered by authorized emissaries of The United States of America" and states that "Permission to explore must be obtained from the government of The United States of America", a clipping from Doubt magazine stating that those in the Dallas area who need prayer can call UN-6181 to reach an answering service directed by Dr. Welsh of the East Dallas Christian Church, a clipping relating a dialogue between A Reporter and Strauss, in which Strauss declares that an H-bomb can be made "as large as you wish, as large as the military requirements demands, that is to say, an H-bomb can be made as - large enough to take out a city", a clipping that reports on Eisenhower's faith the United States to pull through "the present dangerous times", declaring that "America is the greatest force that God has ever allowed to rest on His footstool", a bullet-point clipping discussing the time factors that impede the necessity of evacuating a city in order to save it from a Hydrogen Bomb, a cut ticket that reads "Admit to St. Alphage, London Wall, Churchyard", and a clipping describing the confusion and lack of organizational support that takes place in a crisis.

This page features a large article detailing the sentencing of Lord Montagu, Peter Wildeblood, and Michael Pitt-Rivers titled "12-Month Sentence on Lord Montagu: Verdicts in Indecency Trial". Also related to this case, Morgan has included a small clipping that describes a crowd of about 300 people watching McNally and Reynolds leave the court, some of whom "booed and jeered", and a small article dated 7 November 1954, which states that "Lord Montagu of Beaulieu was released secretly from Wakefield jail yesterday morning after serving eight months of the 12 months' sentence imposed last March". Below the large clipping, Morgan has included a 1761 clipping that describes an "eminent tradesman" who "was detected in attempting that horrible sin, now so much in practice, and taken in custody; but on giving 2000 l. security, he was admitted to bail". Other text clippings on this page include a small clipping that reads "Good New Bra The 'Good News' bra stays up" and a short clipping from Doubt magazine which reports on an "unnamed Russ engineer on the Moscow radio" who "suggests building a damn across the Bering Strait separating the Pacific and the Arctic Oceans". The engineer claims that the dam would allow "warm Pacific water into the cold Arctic" and so "produce an artificial warm current about equal to that of the Gulf Stream, greatly moderating the climate in the Arctic Zone and North-Eastern Asia". Images on this page include a colour photograph of a person paddling a small boat near large rock formations, a black and white clipping of a human eye, a captioned black and white reproduction of Peake's "The Jabberwock" illustration, a black and white photograph of several men who appear to be pulling down on something suspended above their heads, a black and white photograph of what appears to be a mask, a black and white 1956 photograph of Marlene Dietrich, which Morgan has dated and has annotated with the initials "MD", a black and white photograph of a shirtless young man wearing a sailor's hat and crossing his arms over his chest, and a colour photograph of jewels and stones. This page also includes a black and white photograph of a headless stone figure, captioned as "Roman Temple Find. Among the finds made in the ruins of the Roman temple in the City is this one - pictured for the first time - part of a stone figure, probably 'Night,' one of the traditional attendants of the god Mithras", which Morgan has dated as September 1954, and black and white photographs of two stone heads, captioned as "Two important discoveries were made on the site of the Roman temple in the City of London last week: left, a marble head of the god Mithras, and, right, a marble head of a youth. It was stated last Tuesday that the cost of preserving the temple would be about £500,000. The Minister of Works promised to consider whether and how the money might be raised".

pages.notes: blue ink spiral doodle, self portrait
pages.desc: This page features a large black and white photograph of a BBC television camera atop the Forth Rail Bridge outside of Edinburgh. Morgan has included the caption as a separate clipping, which reads "On top of the Forth Bridge go the TV cameras for to-night's programme, when viewers will see painters walking on girders 360ft. above the Forth. ABOVE - Cameraman Arthur Reed looks along the bridge towards South Queensferry" and Morgan has dated the clipping as 7 June 1954. Above this clipping Morgan has included a short text-based clipping stated to be from Hankinson's preface to the 1956 edition of Debrett, which reads "On the death of her husband a woman may once again display her arms, but they must be depicted on a lozenge", an original black and white photograph of a lake-front town showing boats in the water, an original photographic self portrait of Morgan taken in a mirror, an original photograph of a large building taken in a square, and a black and white photograph of an airplane in flight. Below the Forth Bridge clipping, Morgan has included a black and white photograph of a young boy swimming with a shark, the full text of Appleton's poem "The Responsibility", an original photograph of a shirtless man standing with his arms raised and his hands behind his head, and a colour photograph of thousands of Australian Gannets on an island, captioned as "Many thousands of birds nest in the colony at Cape Kidnappers, the only one of Australian Gannets on the mainland of New Zealand. One of the parents must always stay to guard the nest until their single offspring is old enough to defend itself, otherwise the egg or young bird would be destroyed by neighbouring birds, the nesting material stolen and the territory itself usurped".

This page features two versions of the same photo of a Hydrogen Bomb exploding. One of the photos is smaller and is in black and white, captioned as "Rocket trails pierce the base of the fireball to measure the blast". The other photo is large and in colour. It appears to be a title or cover page image, as it includes the title "Operation Ivy: The H-Bomb" along the top of the image. In the bottom left corner of the colour clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white original photograph of a nude man who is hugging his knees to his chest and is resting his head on his knees. Also included on this page is a newspaper article with the headline "Napalm bombs made Princess Margaret jump yesterday when she saw an air display at Ahlhorn R.A.F. Station, North Germany". The article describes the display, which included the bombing of two old aircraft on the ground and the firing of four 20 mm. cannon triggered by a button that Margaret pressed. The article also describes Margaret's clothing, saying she was "Dressed in a light blue fitted woollen overcoat, a small white flower hat and white accessories" and comments that "she stood for an hour in the biting wind while the squadron performed ceremonial drills". Also included on this page is a black and white photograph of a man in a posing pouch extending his leg upwards in what appears to be a dance pose, an original black and white photograph of a nude man with a towel wrapped around his waist, and a black and white photograph of a man riding a horse.

This page is themed around the myxomatosis virus outbreak among rabbits. The page displays many black and white photographs of rabbits, including healthy rabbits, a photograph of a displayed rabbit skeleton, a photograph of a statue showing a hunting scene that includes rabbits, dogs, and horses, and a black and white photograph of a rabbit corpse, which is pasted onto the bottom left corner of a colour photograph of a dried lake, captioned as "A dry lake, called a playa, lies in the bottom of a valley in the Sonoran Desert". The dead rabbit photograph is captioned as "Below: a myxomatous rabbit From 'The Rabbit" [the clipping caption is slightly cut off, so Morgan has finished both of the occurrances of the word rabbit in blue ink]. Also included on this page is a colour photograph of two rabbits being stroked by a person, a black and white photograph of an animal with large eyes, and a black and white photograph of a young man who is seated and is pointing what might be a gun into the air. The main article on this page is titled "The Doom of the Rabbit", which reports that Mr. Milne, a Scottish farmer, brought a diseased rabbit corpse back from England to infect rabbits on his property and is now receiving many requests for other corpses from farmers around Scotland. Onto the lower portion of this clipping, Morgan has pasted a smaller clipping that reads "blind, deaf and paralysed before he is exterminated", describing the awful state in which infected rabbits die. Other articles include a report that the rabbit disease has been identified in Ireland, a short clipping by Seligman describing how to kill a suffering diseased rabbit quickly by stepping on its neck and pulling its back legs, thus avoiding direct contact with its head or neck (said to be "often a mass of sores"), a bullet-point article describing a timeline for myxomatosis, including the artificial introduction of the virus by Sir Charles Martin at Cambridge and the spread of the virus around France and Australia, a short clipping stating that rabbits do £70,000,000 in damage a year in Great Britain, but that myxomatosis causes the creatures to die "in agony", and an article titled "France Imports Rabbits", which describes the import of "Thirty-six American cottontail rabbits" to France in "an attempt to build up the rabbit population devastated by myxomatosis".

The top portion of this page focuses on the sinking of the Titanic, and the series of miscommunications that surrounded the first reports about the disaster. The four clippings included are from 1912 and are titled "Titanic Disaster. Sunk After Collison with an Iceberg. Wireless Calls for Aid. Passengers Rescued by Other Liners", "Icebergs in the Atlantic. A Field Seventy Miles in Length", "Number of Survivors Now Said to be 705", and "Aspects of the Disaster". The lower part of the page includes a black and white reproduction of Tanguy's surrealist painting "Slowly Toward the North", as well as a photograph of Tanguy and two articles. The first article cites an interview with Tanguy, including a statement by Tanguy, which is quoted as "Seeking is the important thing, not painting. You may think painting is to show something new, but no: Picasso and Dali do that, and they are monkeys. I don't want to show anything, or to teach anything". Morgan has annotated this clipping as being from 1954. Beside this, Morgan has included a second clipping with a statement from Tanguy that reads: "Sir: In reference to your Aug. 30 article under the heading "Séance in Connecticut": You have quoted me as saying that Dali and Picasso are monkeys. As I do not mean to doubt the veracity of your art editor, it is evident that there was a misunderstanding because of my difficulty in expressing myself in English. I believe, and said so, that the young artists who think they are saying something by changing their style or type of painting - as Dali and Picasso have done - are monkeys. This is strictly what I intended to convey . . . Yves Tanguy". Also included on this page is the full text of Graves' poem "The Clearing", a black and white photograph of a dog, a black and white photograph of three men standing in a camp, two with their shirts partially off, a black and white photograph of a person holding a camera up to their eye, and a colour reproduction of painting showing columns and a figure in red clothing and a white headpiece in the background.

This page features a large clipping titled "'It Crossed City, Left Vapour Trails'", detailing a sighting of a flying saucer by a Glasgow man named Thomas Robertson. Robertson describes the spinning disc he saw in the air and asserts that he had never before seen photographs of a flying saucer, nor could he have described "what a flying saucer might look like". The article reports that neither Renfrew or Prestwick airports were active the day of the sighting, and no comment was provided by controllers from either airport about whether or not they thought the sighting was plausible. The article includes a photograph of Robertson and another man, possibly the reporter who wrote the article. Next to this clipping, Morgan has included two letters from the Evening News's "You Write" section. The first is from Mr. Darby, and although Darby says he saw a vapour trail at a different time than Robertson, he confirms that he saw something too. The second letter is from an anonymous writer who signs off as "Navigator". This writer states that "In the relative quiet of the countryside to the east of Glasgow, I watched this object fly around for almost twenty minutes. Beyond any doubt it was a twin jet of the Meteor or Canberra type. It had a decided twin trail and the sound of the jets could be heard". Also included on this page is a black and white photograph of an ornate quiver, captioned as "A coating of a Scythian quiver" and dated by Morgan as being from 3 BC, a black and white photograph of an engraving showing three figures arranged vertically, an original black and white photograph of a woman on a bicycle, a black and white photograph of a dog balancing four teacups and a saucer on his nose, and a large colour photograph of the outside of a blast furnace. In the left hand corner of this colour clipping, Morgan has pasted a colour photograph of the torso and lower body of a man leaning back in a chair. In the bottom left corner of chair clipping, Morgan has pasted a third clipping that reads "1 Only - Rocking Chair £12" and then, in letters typed upside on the clipping, "Less than half price! Spindle back".

This page focuses on a long article that recounts Mr. Beesley's experience of the sinking of the Titanic. Also included on this page is a short clipping that appears to have a typo in the title. The clipping reads "Sinatra's Big Mouth. This is Frank Sinatra's big month. He stars in two excellent films showing in 30 cinemas throughout Southern California". The images on this page include an original black and white photograph of a naked man wearing a hat and kneeling down while holding a guitar in front of his groin, a black and white photograph that Morgan has annotated as "Ben Nevis summit c.1900", a black and white photograph of a man on a sailing boat, and a black and white photograph of a man lying on the ground in what looks to be a forest. As Patterson in her spreadsheet for the Digitising the Edwin Morgan Scrapbooks project notes, this man may be a soldier.

This page includes three clippings discussing the Titanic. The first clipping reports the number of passengers, officers, and crew on board the Titanic, and the numbers rescued, which Morgan has annotated as coming "from the Surviving Passengers Committee". The second clipping is titled as "The Death Roll. Official Figures", as reported by Reuters, although these numbers are lower than those in the first clipping. The final clipping is titled "The Three Pearl Necklaces" and states that "The London Insurance Market was much relieved on Saturday to receive advices from friends in the United States" that three expensive and insured pearl necklaces belonging to a surviving passenger had all been saved from the Titanic. Other clippings on this page include a short article that states that William Garnett "won more than £10,000 on football pools" and yet had to appear in court for bankruptcy, a Hurst Hospital raffle ticket numbered 1496, and a clipping from a flyer advertising various bingo games with prizes. Images on this page include a black and white photograph of a cat, an original black and white photograph of a woman seated at a table, an original black and white photograph of a mechanical crane, an original colour photograph of a shirtless man seated and posing on a small pillar, a black and white photographic self portrait of Morgan taken while he is looking down at a mirror placed on the floor, a black and white photographic self portrait of Morgan wearing a kilt taken while looking down at a small mirror placed on the floor, a black and white photograph of the Ailsa Craig rock, a black and white photograph of a shirtless man seated on a stool and posing, a black and white photograph of a man's eyes, forehead, and hair, and a black and white photograph of boats on water, which Patterson has described in her spreadsheet for the Digitising the Edwin Morgan Scrapbooks project as Chinese junk boats. Also included on this page is an advertisement for £75,000 to be won for "filling in your Vernons" which shows a trail of printed footprints. Onto this advertisement, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of a young man's face, a black and white reproduction of a drawing of a god-like figure dressed in a robe and standing against a starry background, and a peach-coloured plastic foot that is similar in shape and size to three black footprints drawn on the Vernon's ad. Morgan has placed the plastic foot in sequence with the printed footprints of the advertisement.

This page features a large colour photograph showing a Hydrogen Bomb exploding. Morgan has annotated the upper right corner of the clipping with "H-Bomb" and in the upper left corner of the clipping, Morgan has pasted a large colour photograph of a man's fist, which extends down toward the center of the clipping where the most concentrated part of the explosion is visible. Above this large clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of four boys running from something while a crowd of people appears to be watching, an original photograph of what looks to be an obelisk and a person on a bicycle in front of a body of water, a black and white photograph of a bullfighter waving his cape at a bull, a black and white photograph of a person in a mountainous wooded area carrying a large load on their back, a colour photograph of a figure on a rocky beach standing in front of a rock formation, a black and white photograph of a young boy dressed in a suit, a black and white photograph of several young men standing in a line, looking away and to the side, and a black and white photograph of a rough stone sculpture of a religious figure in a large hat with his hands held in the sign of benediction. Text-based clippings on this page include a phrase from Tiller's "Science Fiction" reading "Why do my fingers freeze upon the blaster", a clipping that reads "Outcry for Death", a quotation from Rev. Booth that states "It were better that the whole world should be destroyed than that Communism should triumph", a handwritten clipping quoting Galt that reads "There are few shorter roads to the pit than through the kirk-door", a clipping that speaks against "the Doctrine and Practice of Christianity inconsistent with the Happiness of Mankind", a clipping reading "The bigger the bomb the", followed by a separate clipping reading "BETTER", a clipping that states that the Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Fisher, does not believe the hydrogen bomb to be "the greatest danger of today", because all it would do is to "sweep a vast number of persons at one moment from this world into the other, and more vital world, into which, anyhow, they must all pass some time", a 1956 clipping stating that Quiro, a Filipino preacher, "predicted in Manila that June 24, 1956, may be doomsday - in the form of a guided missile of heaven's own", and a clipping reading "Go Thou, and be a Stone". Morgan has also included a 1955 clipping that discusses Cooper's invention of the Arcaid, a "blind-deaf machine, something like a small portable typewriter". The clipping states that Cooper was inspired by an airman rendered deaf and blind, with whom Cooper shared a hospital room. The machine is said to cost £50 and is already in use by "a blind and deaf woman who uses it in her favourite cafe".

pages.notes: blue and red ink spiral doodles
pages.desc: This page features a large colour photograph of a desert scene with a red rock hill in the foreground. Along the top right corner of the clipping, Morgan has pasted a clipping that reads "Is There Life on Mars?". Extending from the bottom left corner of the large clipping and reaching upwards, Morgan has also pasted a large colour photograph of a hand gripping a ridged object. Above the collage clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of the corpse of conjoined twin babies, captioned as "9. Double-headed human monster (from Et. Wolff La science des monstres, Gallimard), a black and white photograph of a man holding a large bow that rests on the floor in front of him and is almost as tall as him, a small original black and white photograph of a man standing in a posing pouch, a black and white clipping that appears to be a photograph of water, a black and white photograph of a shirtless man reclining on one elbow, and a large black and white photograph of two young boys, one standing and one sitting, both with their arms crossed and looking away from the camera. Also included on this page is an article titled "The Fleeting Flesh", which recounts the research of Dr. Aebersold and states that "About 98% of the atoms in the human body are renewed each year". The article goes on to discuss Aebersold's methods using radioisotopes, and states that the human body "should not be considered permanent in any material sense," although in a larger sense, "the atoms that each human body is made of were once parts of other living things . . . The atoms that made up Plato and Henry VIII are still floating around as parts of people now living". A second article on this page discusses the Grauballe Man and his display in Denmark following the successful preservation of the body by Hr. Lange-Kornbak. The Grauballe Man is said to be so well preserved that "police were able to take fingerprints", while researchers have surmised that the man was likely a nobleman who submitted to being made a human sacrifice to "Nerthsu" (likely a misspelling for Nerthus), the goddess of fertility. The article also discusses the Tollund man, who was not preserved and so remains now only as a head. A final clipping advertises treatment of "Rheumatism and Circulation Diseases" by "A. Welsh Coutts, M.A.P.H." for 7s 6d.

This page features a large colour photograph of a what appears to be a red explosion in a night sky (likely an H-Bomb). In the bottom left corner of the clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of a sculpture of a man who is bent forward, leaning on one arm with the other arm raised. Above this collage, Morgan has pasted a 1954 black and white photograph of Brando leaning against a television set and looking down at a cat and a clock, both of which sit on top of the television. The photograph is captioned as "Brando at Home in Hollywood" and is accredited to Garrett. Also included on this page is a colour photograph of a white sea bird in flight, a black and white photograph of a man dressed in a kilt and blowing on a horn, a black and white head-shot photograph of a young man, a black and white photographic portrait of Hopkins, which Morgan has annotated with the initials "GMH", and a black and white photograph of a small piglet standing on top of a larger pig, which appears to be sleeping. Text-based clippings on this page include a short clipping that reads "Reporting a loss of £1000 on the college gardens, Mr. R.L. Scarlett, Musselburgh, said: 'We are in the red.'", a short clipping titled "Brando Departs", which reports that Brando "cut short his holiday in the tiny cottage home of his fiancée, Mlle. Josianne [sic] Berender at Bandol, France" and states that Berender was "weeping at the window as he drove off", and a clipping subtitled as "No Wings", which describes a flying saucer sighting in East Kilbride outside of Glasgow. The article quotes a witness as stating "At one time it looked round and the next moment it looked like a banana ... It had no wings and at first I thought it was a helicopter, but it couldn't have been, it was too big". A larger article on this page discusses new research being done on the disposal of "radio-active wastes". The article states that a "cheap clay, shredded and baked until it resembles Chinese noodles" might allow radio-active waste to be handled and disposed of easily, as well as potentially offering "a practical method of packaging radioactive materials as useful sources of energy". The article concludes on a cynical note, stating "Then, too, after fluoride has gone out of style, the dentists can discover that radioactive noodles are exactly what city water needs to make us all grow teeth again, in the gums where today's panacea has defanged us. Cr Mitchell".

This page features a large colour photograph of a mushroom cloud over water. In the lower left hand corner of the clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of the Statue of Liberty as seen directly from the bottom of the statue looking up. The page also features a large colour photograph of a man with a headpiece and belt decorated in shells squatting beside a young boy. The man is adjusting a similar shell headpiece to his own on the boy's head, and the boy's face has been painted white. Other images on the page include a black and white photograph of a New York baseball player captured in mid-air as he catches a ball, a black and white photograph of two male dancers, which has been pasted into the lower left corner of a black piece of paper before being pasted into the scrapbook, an original photograph of what appears to be a bicycle show, a sepia photograph of a long line of ice skaters on an outdoor ice track in a snowy, forested area, and a black and white photograph of two kilted male dancers, to which Morgan has attached the caption "'The Double Swords', danced by Bruce McClure and Andrew Rollo (principal dancers of the Celtic Ballet)". Text-based clippings on this page include a short clipping that states that an "Ice-chunk 2 feet by 1 foot by 2 inches" fell "from a clear warm sky over North Fresno, Calif." Although there are claims that the ice-chunk "came from a jet plane", the clipping states that the "pilot said it did not". A second short clipping describes new research into a mechanical process of extracting eggs from their shells and placing them "into individual plastic packets, with a spot of carbon dioxide added 'to maintain quality'. The clipping states that "The shells of course will be saved to house artificial eggs".

This page features a large Max comic by Giovannetti showing Max drinking a concoction from a test tube, growing a lot of hair, drinking another concoction, losing the hair, and then using the fallen hair to stuff a pillow. Next to this comic is a black and white photograph of two boys standing outside near two large pillars and a black and white photograph of a kilted man who may be a solider. Below these clippings is a large black and white photograph of two trains, which Morgan has annotated as "American Freight-trains 1954".

This page includes a facsimile reproduction of the first page of a letter from Dylan Thomas to Marguerite Caetani in which he profusely apologizes for not finishing a piece for her. Morgan has annotated the letter as "[Dylan Thomas]". Next to this letter, Morgan has included a colour photograph of a long, bare tree with a few bare branches extending. The tree is silhouetted against a colourful sky. Below the letter, Morgan has included a black and white photograph of a nude man standing with his back mostly to the camera, his arms outstretched and his head thrown back, a colour photograph of a person shown from the back standing in a wooded area in the snow, a black and white photograph of a stand of trees, a black and white captioned reproduction of Friedrich's "The Churchyard in the Snow" painting, and an original black and white photograph of a shirtless man posing in a straw hat with a fishing net strung up behind him. Along the bottom of the original photograph, Morgan has pasted a single line of text that reads "Recently my hat was blown off while exposing."

The bottom of this page is taken up by one half of a double-page, black and white photograph of the Brooklyn Bridge at night, captioned on this half as "Brooklyn Bridge is an aerial flight over New York's East River held by steel gossamers slung between tremendous stone Gothic towers." Into the bottom right corner of the clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of Roebling, the civil engineer who designed the bridge, as well as a small line of text in the upper left hand corner that reads "It was dark when Morgan went to the bridge". Above this collage, Morgan has pasted two parts from Gascoyne's "Night Thoughts" poem, as well as adding several ellipses in blue ink to the end of the last line of the poem's excerpt, which reads "But listen, it begins again, I think". Also included are a short 1955 clipping stating that "The longest run of any show at one theatre is 'The Drunkard', which ran daily at the Theatre Mart, Los Angeles, from July 6, 1933, to September 6, 1953", a short Evening Times clipping reporting that Dr. White, doctor to President Eisenhower, has left on "an expedition to record the heartbeat of a whale", a black and white photograph of a man in elbow pads and gloves who appears to be struggling on the ground with something, a black and white image that may be a photograph of a piece of art with a small human figure being suspended upside-down by wires, and a black and white photograph of a man in a jacket standing outside in front of a building.

The bottom of this page is taken up by the second half of a double-page photograph of the Brooklyn Bridge lit up at night (started on page 2275), captioned on this half with "Here the 1,595-foot-long span is seen at dusk from the Brooklyn side against the brilliantly lighted towers of downtown Manhattan". In the right hand corner of the clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of a man looking away from the camera and posed to face the bridge. In the upper right corner of the clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of the Brooklyn Bridge taken during the day. Above this collage, Morgan has pasted a 1954 black and white photograph of many workers on a wide stretch of land, captioned as "Working site of the Shihlungkuochland Reservoir. When completed in June of this year, the reservoir will free 16,660 hectares of land in this area from threat of drought and flood". In between the two larger clippings, Morgan has included a black and white photograph of a gopher standing on its hind legs, a black and white photograph of two men running through what appears to be rubble, a black and white photograph of a nude man stretched out on a cushioned bench and reaching down for a blanket, and a black and white photograph of a man lying face down on the ground in a public place, with one man kneeling down beside him and the shoes of other people visible in the clipping. Also included is a brief clipping describing interactions between Mahler and Freud. The article says that Freud remarked about Mahler that "he had never met anyone who understood pyscho-analysis so quickly". Mahler is said to have "remembered a hurdy-gurdy playing 'Ach, du lieber Augustin' in the street during an emotional crisis of childhood, and realised that this bathos must always be echoed in his symphonies".

This page contains a large article by Crankshaw, focusing on a report by Kinsey, titled "The Sexual Behaviour of the American Female", and the reception this work has received in the Soviet Union. The article focuses on an attack by Leonov on Kinsey's book and discusses the ways in which sexual politics and family life are being framed, politicized, and discussed in the Soviet Union. Overall, Leonov sees Kinsey as "an instrument in the campaign 'to make man into beast, to spread the law of the animal world over human society in order to pervert and falsify the laws of social development, to justify war, to justify the lack of rights and the poverty of the workers, to justify the law of 'might is right''". Leonov concludes that the book is "the most cheap kind of pornographic hash, clumsily disguised as science". Below this clipping is a large black and white photograph of several young men dressed in suits and smoking cigarettes. In the top right corner of the clipping, Morgan has written "London 1954", and in the bottom left corner, he has pasted a line of text that reads "Will assist Strangers living in London to meet the RIGHT people". The page includes several other short articles, including a 1954 article on the return of Diego Rivera to Mexico's Communist Party at age 67 after his excommunication years earlier, which includes a photograph of Rivera, a clipping discussing the bombing of Hiroshima and the excitement amongst victims when a rumour suggested that "'Japan had the same mysterious weapon' as that used against them and that a squadron of Japanese bombers had now used it on the mainland of America", an article describing the arrest of an armed youth at a dance in Paisley, and a report on Dr. Delgado and his mind control experiments on monkeys. The Delgado clipping is very critical and concludes by wondering what Delgado does when not running currents through monkeys, suggesting "Cannibalism, perhaps?". Images on the page include a black and white photograph of a shirtless man lying on the ground leaning against a wagon wheel wearing a cowboy hat, jeans, and boots, a black and white photograph that may be a still from a movie showing a large robot and several men, one of whom appears to be pointing a gun at the robot, an original black and white photograph of a shirtless man sitting cross-legged on the ground, a black and white photograph of a human eye, a black and white cartoon drawing of a shirtless man in water scratching his torso, captioned as "The solution? 'Coming up to scratch.' In Figures of Speech (Gollancz: 8s 6d) by Mervyn Peake", and a black and white film still from 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea showing a group of people in scuba diving gear walking on the sea floor.

At the top of this page is a large black and white photograph of three boys lying on their stomachs on a beach. Two of them are playing chess, while the third watches. In the bottom left corner, Morgan has written "Odessa 1954" in blue ink. Beside this clipping, Morgan has included a black and white photograph of group of men in kilts, one of whom is holding a bagpipe, and a black and white photograph of a man wearing only underwear standing with his back to the camera while he stretches something between his arms behind his back. Below this, Morgan has included an article recapping reports on "youthful alcoholism and hooliganism" in the Soviet Union from the Central Press. The end of the article briefly mentions that, in addition to drunkenness and violence, "Trud [publication], for instance, attacks the euphemistically named 'butterflies' who prowl the centre of Moscow at night for 'good times,' men and money". Two other small text-based clipping are also included, the first recounting a story that Dame Melba "never went on to the platform to sing without first receiving her cheque, which she thrust into the bosom of her dress", and the second said to be a notice in an agency window that reads "WANTED - A domesticated lady to live with an elderly lady to hell with the cooking and housework". This page also includes a large colour reproduction of Copley's "Boy with Squirrel" painting and a black and white photograph of a white horse splashing through water. Onto the clipping of the horse, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of a sculpture of two men in a curling wave and a black and white photograph of a shirtless man posing in a sailor's hat.

The bottom half of this page is taken up by a colour photograph of several sailing boats on the water. Above this clipping, Morgan has included an original colour photograph of a shirtless man seated on a short pillar, a sepia photograph of a skier standing outside surrounded by snow, a black and white photograph of a man in a suit talking to a second man, who is scantily dressed as a Roman soldier and is holding a long chain that is serving as a leash for a large cat (possibly a cougar), a black and white photograph of a man dressed only in underwear standing outside in the summer holding what look to be ski poles, a colour photograph of two red mushrooms, captioned as "Vermilion Parasols of gill fungus Mycena are edible mushrooms, despite their poisonous colour. Unlike most fungus shoots, they live for months", a black and white photograph of Joyce dressed in a suit, a hat, a cane, and an eyepatch, and a colour reproduction of Chih-Fu's painting "Narcissus". Also included on this page is an article discussing a dispute of ownership regarding "thirty-seven Picasso paintings (valued at about half a million dollars)". The paintings are owned by the Soviet Union, but while on loan to Paris for an exhibit, Mme. Keller-Shchukin claimed that she had originally owned the paintings before the Soviets "illegally confiscated the paintings without compensation". A French judge eventually ruled that the "French courts had no jurisdiction over the Bolshevik revolution and its artistic policies". The article also quotes Picasso, who stated "What would happen if, one of these days, the Comte de Paris (pretender to the French throne) should get a notion into his head to claim ownership of the Louvre and the Palace of Versailles?" A second small text-based clipping is included on this page, titled "Clippiegram". The clipping is in Scots and reads: See thon conductor wi' the Yoonie scarf - says he's daein' maths wi' Nat Phil - peety Nat cannae learn him to get his money right, but."

The bottom two thirds of this page feature a large colour photograph of a young solider. Above this photograph, Morgan has included a French language clipping discussing the density of stars in the Hercules constellation and showing a black and white photograph of part of the constellation taken by a powerful telescope. He has also included a short 1957 clipping titled "Poles Apart", which states that a Polish man taking oath in court said that he would give "the truth, the whole truth, and anything but the truth", before being corrected and repeating the oath correctly. Morgan has also included a short clipping stating that Picasso decided to move from his villa in Vallauris to a new villa in Cannes that he purchased for £12,000. Picasso is quoted as saying "For the first time in my life I shall not be living in a shed and I am a landowner . . . At last I shall have space. At Vallauris people wandered into my place as if it were a hotel".

A colour title page from Collier's 22 March 1952 article "Man Will Conquer Space Soon". The title page features a colour drawing of a spacecraft, a small yellow planet or moon, and the circular rotating space station drawn by von Braun. The title page also includes a colour photograph of several men sitting around a boardroom table, with the caption "Some of the scientists and illustrators who took part in Collier's symposium (left to right): Rolf Klep, Willy Ley, Dr. Heinz Haber, Dr. Wernher von Braun, Dr. Fred L. Whipple, and Chesley Bonestell". On a large desk in front of the men in the photograph is a desk with many papers and notepads, and on one of these notepads, Morgan has written the date 1952 in pink pen. Onto this full-page clipping and above the photograph of the men, Morgan has pasted in a colour photograph of a book open to an illustrated page that appears to show two astronauts on a red planet with a Saturn-like planet visible in the sky. Above the title, "Man Will Conquer Space Soon" Morgan has pasted in the clipped word "Forse", which translates in Italian to "Maybe". In the bottom right corner of the full-page clipping, Morgan has included a black and white photograph of a naked man lying with his back to the camera. The man's legs are extended beside him and he is propped up on one elbow, with his other arm extended upwards. Above the full-page clipping, Morgan has included a black and white photograph of a sculpture that includes a carved human ear, and in to the upper left corner, Morgan has pasted a caption, which identifies the sculpture as  "F.E. McWilliam. Head in Extended Order. Study for a pediment. 1948. Hoptonwood Stone. Length 24 ins.". Morgan has also included a movement sequence black and white photograph of a male dancer in tights and a white shirt, and a black and white photograph of a boy dressed in a suit standing in front of a parking lot full of cars. The boy is holding something black in his hands, although it is not clear what.

A large colour reproduction of a whimsical drawing by Emett takes up the bottom half of this page. A version of this illustration appeared as part of a portfolio by Emett for Life magazine in 1954. Above this clipping, Morgan has included the caption written by Emett for this drawing in Life, which reads "White Sands Proving Ground, New Mexico. Everybody knows that other planets are becoming keenly interested in the scientific goings-on in the desert. Here a flying saucer, slightly off course, has landed and is carefully dissecting a piece of pure American science to see what makes it tick." The "American science" referred to appears to be a train engine. Other images on the page include a black and white photograph of Emett with one of his inventions, captioned as "Emett, fully equipped for his U.S. Tour", a black and white photograph of a kitten, a small black and white photograph of a young man dressed in a posing pouch squatting down, a black and white headshot of a young man in profile, a black and white photograph of a young man standing on a beach posing and flexing his arms while wearing a bathing suit, a black and white photograph of three men standing indoors, each with a drink in their hand, which Morgan has annotated as being taken in 1955 and under which he has written the names Jon Silkin, Peter Russell, and Alec Craig, a black and white original photograph of a nude man straddling a bench-like seat, a dark black and white photographic headshot of a young man taken in profile, a black and white photograph of a man suspended by his feet from a bridge captioned in Italian as "Toronto. Emulo del famoso mago Houdini, James Todd appeso per i piedi e chiuso in una camicia di forza, si libera dai lacci in pochi minuti. La foto a destra, lo mostra durante l'esercizio", and a black and white photograph of a man (possibly Todd again) hanging upside down from a pulley hook and bound in a strait jacket. Text-based clippings on the page include a short clipping titled "A Singular Clergyman", which describes Mr. Pettigrew, a clergyman who once took off his wig when feeling warm and set it on his hat. He forgot he had done so, however, and, thinking the wig missing, asked a woman "if she had seen a hassock o' hair among her feet". The article also states that the clergyman only laughed three times in his life, one of those taking place when a pudding on the fire "happened to cheep from the expulsion of air" during grace, causing a small child present to say "Weesht, weesht, pudy, . . . naebody maun speak here, but the man 'at seeks the blessing". The second text-based clipping is a short clipping that appears below the photograph of the cat, and reads "If your cat is lively most of the time, eats all its food and keeps it down, and there is no obvious sign of illness, then you can be sure there is nothing very seriously wrong with it, whatever other strange things it may be doing".

pages.notes: blue and red ink doodle with shading that aligns with the pillar clipping
pages.desc: This page features a large colour photograph of two people fishing downstream of a large waterfall, a large black and white photograph taken from Life magazine showing a steel mill in Dusseldorf Germany with the steel workers bicycling home from work in the foreground, and a large clipping dealing with the sentencing of Hulme and Parker, two sixteen-year-olds found guilty of murdering Parker's mother. The clipping headline reads "After six days of sensational evidence, two 16-year-old girls, Juliet Hulme and Pauline Parker, were found guilty in Wellington, New Zealand, yesterday of murdering Pauline's mother. Without a trace of emotion, they heard the judge sentence them to be detained during Her Majesty's pleasure. As sentence was passed on Pauline, a young man in the gallery shouted, 'I protest, I object'". The article states that the objecting man was removed from the courtroom. In addition to discussing the details of the murder and describing the girls as showing "calm detachment", the article suggests that there were "abnormal sexual relations between the girls", and also states that "Medical opinion on their [the girls'] sanity was divided." Above this article, Morgan has pasted a text-based clipping, which reads "A Story of Adventure in New Zealand." Other text-based clippings on this page include a short piece titled "Strong-man vandal," which reports that "Twelve telephone directories have been torn in two in Salisbury kiosks during 11 days", an article that describes how to train yourself to swallow saws, stating that you should "Begin with a smooth iron bar, bent at a right angle at the top to keep it from slipping all the way down your throat.
