Tickle the back of your throat with it for a practice period every day until the gagging reflex is subdued, and then just let it slide down slowly," and an article clipping that describes the behavior of a man named Williams who would approach women, including a woman named Paddington, and ask them to stand on his stomach. Due to his actions with Paddington, Williams was charged. He defended himself by stating that he did so because "he was interested in weight-lifting" and that "he had had a serious accident on a motor cycle and felt he was not responsible for his actions." Images on this page include a black and white photograph of a man in his underwear kneeling on the floor and bending at the waist with his hands extended in front of him on the floor, a black and white photograph of a shirtless man holding what appears to be a bar above his head, a black and white photograph of a leaning pillar, behind which a man's arm and leg can be seen, a black and white photograph of a naked man lying on his stomach on a bench, and a black and white reproduction of a self-portrait painted by Stanley Spencer.

The bottom of this page is taken up by a large colour advertisement from Life Magazine showing the interior of a car, which is blue and white, as well as a handbag, a bouquet of flowers, blue gloves, and a necklace with blue and white stones sitting on the backseat. Through the side window of the car, a red car with a man in the driver's seat is visible. The advertisement is captioned as "Unretouched color photo of Dodge Royal V-8 Sport Coupe interior. Through window, Royal V-8 4-Door Sedan". In the lower left corner, Morgan has annotated the clipping as being from 1954, and he has also pasted in a small clipping that reads "Did you know that slugs keep perfectly for a fortnight in a Cellophane bag full of parsley? They are as good as new when released." Above this large clipping, Morgan has included a black and white photograph of Garbo, captioned as "Gosta Berling's Saga: Greta Garbo in the Swedish film which first made her famous", a small black and white photograph of a man in a long jacket walking on the street with a man in uniform also visible behind him, a black and white photograph of a stack of logs behind a gate with a sign reading "These elm logs are for coffin manufacture. DRIVE CAREFULLY. J. Gliksten & Son Ltd.", a colour photograph of a man in a colourful robe and a green hat who appears to have a growth under his chin, a black and white photograph of two boys, one of whom is being shown a piece of paper, and a black and white photograph of three older women standing under an umbrella, captioned as "Hopeful Landowners, Mrs. Albert H. Cook (right) and daughter-in-law, Mrs. Preesang (left), ward off blistering Texas sun with umbrella as they watch the test. The Delp well was drilled on Cook farm. When the well came in, Mrs. cook and her husband jubilantly greased each other's cheeks." Above the clipping of the women, Morgan has pasted in two lines of text, which together make up a headline that likely comes from the same article as the photograph. The headline reads "Waiting in Texas to Get Rich Quick". Other text-based clippings include a brief article written by Mrs Dainty, which recounts the story of her nephew labelling his bag for summer camp with the label "In case of accidents, this was David Gray," and an article describing a ceremony performed by the Pope, in which a "glittering crown of diamonds, topazes, sapphires, and aquamarines" was fixed "to a painting of the Madonna" supposed to have been painted by St. Luke. The ceremony "instituted a new feast devoted to the 'Queen of Heaven'" and included "25 cardinals and 385 bishops". The article also reports that it was seen by over 300,000 people in person, was televised for Italians, and was "broadcast over nearly half the national radio networks of Europe." Morgan has included the headline of this article in his clipping, but he has altered it by pasting in a second clipping that reads "Queen Mother", which alters the whole headline to read "Pope Crowns Picture of Queen Mother".

This page includes two Emett drawings. The first is a large colour drawing showing cowboys around a fire at night, captioned as "Wyoming. Evening on the range". The second is a black and white drawing of a figure on a bicycle throwing the morning paper at a house. The impact of paper is shown as shattering the house. The drawing is captioned "Sunday morning". Both images are from the Life magazine publication of Emett's drawings in America. This page also includes a black and white photograph of a carved sculpture, captioned as "tribal chieftain, Nuragic period; height 11 7/16 inches" and annotated by Morgan with the word "Sardinia", a black and white reproduction of Delahaye's 1875 drawing of Rimbaud, a colour photograph of a ship at sea with the words "south" and "good" visible on its side, a black and white photograph of four boys seated on a bench taken from the back, a black and white photograph of two men working, one of whom is carrying a potted plant and one of whom is hammering, and a black and white photograph of a large manned flying machine in flight. Morgan has included a short article clipping to accompany the flying machine photograph. The article explains that this "is the 'flying bedstead', Britain's new Heath-Robinson style 'plane with no wings. The 'plane which is lifted by the thrust of twin-jet engines flew for nearly 10 minutes at heights of 5 to 10ft. on its maiden flight". The article goes on to quote the Ministry of Supply as they describe the light framework, which was designed with existing engines, and the work yet to be done on "the problems of heat, noise, safety, and the design of the most efficient engines and an airframe to employ this principle". At the top of the page, Morgan has also included a small line of text, which reads "Queen Elizabeth was sometimes called a virgin, but only behind her back."

This page includes a French clipping about Picasso that Morgan has annotated as being by Cocteau in 1953, a short clipping that states "there is, alas! no scientific confirmation for the existence of the hoop snake that has so often been seen, in the rye whiskey and applejack regions of the United States, bowling rapidly along the road with its tail in its mouth like a wheel without spokes", and four numbered black and white photographs with the collective caption "In the Zoological Institute one can see quite a number of animals which until recently were quite unknown to science. 1. A new genus of Amphipoda. 2. A fish caught at a depth of 23,714 feet. 3. A butterfly caught in the Southern Kazakhstan steppes and not yet classified. 4. A new echinoderm discovered near the Kuril Islands". Above this caption, Morgan has added the date 1954 and has written "Leningrad" above the words "Zoological Institute". Morgan has also added a number 4 to the corner of the fourth photograph, as the number seems to have been clipped away. Other captioned photographs on this page include a carved statue captioned as "Figure carrying a vase", which Morgan has annotated as "Sardinia B.C.", a black and white photograph of a carved animal statue captioned as "cow(?) standing, from the Abini group; length 3 1/8 inches," and a carved sculpture of a boat with what looks like small animals stacked inside, which is captioned as "Model of a boat with a head of deer carved on the prow" and which Morgan has annotated with "Sardinia B.C.". Other images on this page include an original black and white photograph of a shirtless man photographed from the waist up holding a spear, a black and white photograph of a shirtless woman using a ladle that looks like it is made from a coconut, a colour photograph of a white cat with one green eye and one blue eye, a black and white photograph of an airplane in flight above clouds, a black and white photograph of a young solider standing with his hands in his pockets and wearing a helmet, a small black and white photograph of a white window frame on the side of a dark building, and an original black and white photograph of a nude man seated with his knees bent towards his chest. Also included on this page is a black and white photograph of a man in a speedo standing outside in a rocky landscape flexing his muscles. Onto this clipping, Morgan has pasted a small line of text that reads "Don Reyes".

This page features a large colour photograph of a vast icy landscape. In the upper right corner, Morgan has pasted a colour photograph of a metal airplane. The bottom of the page features a black and white photograph that might show more snow and ice (although it could be sand, or some other material). Extending from the upper left corner of the clipping, Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of a carved stone face. Morgan has cut away where the mouth would be, giving the face a gaping look. In between the upper and lower collages, Morgan has pasted two lines of text that read "AND NOW THE SEA BEGINS TO FREEZE."

This page features a progressive series of yellow-tinted black and white photographs. The first photograph shows a wooden apparatus on a stand with a round hole drilled through it. Each of the following three photographs zoom in a little more on the hole, allowing the viewer to see more and more of the scene behind the apparatus. By the fourth photograph, the hole is no longer the focus. The focus instead becomes two rocks that can be viewed through the hole, one of which is curved and itself has a large circular hole in the middle of it. In the last photograph, the edges of the wooden hole are completely out of the frame and the photograph captures the two rocks unimpeded. Below this sequence, Morgan has then pasted a black and white photograph of a human eye. Other images on this page include a colour photograph of a man who appears to be a soldier in uniform and is holding a gun over his shoulder, a colour photograph of two pipes in a long ditch, onto which Morgan has pasted a black and white photograph of a shirtless man leaning back with his arms behind his head, a black and white photograph of a group of boys in uniform standing on the street and waving their hats, a black and white cartoon of a photographer under a drape sheet setting up to take a photograph of a woman in a burka, and a black and white photograph of a nude man standing in front of a rock formation. The man's back is turned to the camera and he is flexing his arms.

This page includes an original black and white photograph of a naked man crouching down with his head bent, a black and white photograph of a man's face, a black and white photograph of sailing ships in a harbor with their sails open, a black and white photograph of a face, captioned as "MAORI FACE, carved and tattooed in life - an illustration from Carleton Coon's A History of Man," an original photograph of a loch and reflections on the water's surface, a black and white photograph of two men who appear to be nude and wrestling, a black and white reproduction of Lowry's "The Playground', a black and white photograph of a man holding himself up by his arms in a seated position above a chair, a black and white photograph of a man looking through a large camera lens, a black and white photograph of a handwritten sign in French and displayed in a window, which reads "Chambre a louver sur le derriere du boulanger" and offers "couper en deux," an original black and white photograph of a boy in glasses and two uniformed men in an industrial setting, a black and white photograph of a man standing in front of a wall with his hands in his pockets, a black and white photograph of what appears to be stalactites in a cave, or perhaps icicles, a black and white photograph of a boy dressed in a suit, holding flowers and smiling, and a black and white image that may be of clouds or smoke, but is hard to make out. This page also includes a black and white reproduction of a drawing by Tchelitchev, which shows a male figure standing. Around him, are a square and an oval, and it appears that another figure is standing back to back with the man, as the backs of two legs are visible next to the man's legs, and the backs of two arms are visible extending above the man's head. There is also what looks to be a fifth leg extending from the man's hip, although this may perhaps be a suggestion of movement, similar to Da Vinci's Vitruvian Man. The caption reads "Ode. Programme cover by Pavel Tchelitchev (No. 352)". Other clippings on this page include a black and white reproduction of the cover of Calvin Hoffman's 1955 book, The Man Who Was Shakespeare, which displays a portrait of Shakespeare and a portrait of Christopher Marlowe, a printed notice or part of a flier that reads "Other Shakespearian Properties open to Visitors / SHAKESPEARE'S BIRTHPLACE / HENLEY STREET / ANNE HATHAWAY'S COTTAGE / SHOTTERY - 1 mile / NEW PLACE / CHAPEL STREET / MARY ARDEN'S HOUSE / WILMCOTE - 4 miles," a line of text that reads "theories of Artistotle", which is likely an intended pun rather than a typo, a line of text reading "Practice wigwagging indoors; then use it outdoors," and two black and white reproductions of watercolour paintings by Hitler, captioned collectively as "Water colours by the Fuehrer. Above, 'House With a White Fence,' painted during the first World War; below, 'The Old Yard, Munich.'"

pages.notes: Morgan's annotation on the "Look at Your Hands" article indicates that he had no hair on the middle joints of his fingers
pages.desc: This page is a large-scale study on hands. There are many small clipping of hands, including a colour photograph of a woman's hand held in an Indian mudra position, with the woman's gold sleeve and gold bracelet also visible, a colour photograph of a hand holding the neck of a guitar, photographed from the back, two black and white images of skeletal hands, a black and white photograph of a baseball glove, a black and white drawing of a six-fingered hand, various black and white photographs of the hands of statues, and a black and white photograph of a pin-board with hand-shaped pins holding up notes, among others. The page also includes several short lines of text, including the line "Dear Zany Amanuensis: I am amazed to note the", followed by a clipping that reads "Thumb he, / Wizbee, / Longman,/ Cherry Tree, / Little Jack-a-Dandy," a line of text that reads "FREAK HANDS TROUBLESOME", a line of text reading "Fangen-Finger-Fünf," a short clipping in Scots reading "Thumb bold / Thibity-thold Langman,/ Lick pan, / Mammie's wee man," a line of text reading "ILM-UL-KAFF", which refers to the study of hand-reading, a line of text reading "and now Learned Hand," a short text-based clipping written by Dalgleish that recounts his experience of accidentally dropping his artificial right arm when running for a bus, and a short clipping reading "Tom Thumbkin,/ Willie Wilkin,/ Long Daniel,/ Betty Bodkin,/ And Little Dick." Morgan has also included a clipping titled "Look at Your Hands", which recounts a scientific study that claims "people whose ancestors came from different parts of Europe have different distribution of hair on the middle joints of their fingers." Next to a paragraph reading, "If you have no hair at all growing on these joints, your ancestors came from Spain, Italy, or Ireland", Morgan has written "[EM]" with a checkmark. One of the largest clippings on the pages is a black and white photograph from Life magazine of two empty work gloves resting the handles of a drill that is planted in concrete. On the bottom of this clipping, Morgan has pasted a small colour photograph of a hand and a ruffled sleeve. Clippings that appear to be unrelated to hands on this page include a small animal resisting being pulled by leash, a black and white photograph of a group of young men standing outside in school uniform, some of whom appear to be taking photographs, an original black and white photograph of a shirtless man in a sailor hat and white trousers with his arms crossed so that his hands are not visible, and a small colour photograph of an Asian doll's head.

This page includes two black and white clippings that show reproductions of Chinese stamps, as well as providing background for the figures depicted on each stamp. The stamps included are captioned as "Stamp 1, sepia. Legend: 'Chang Heng (A.D. 78-139). Astronomer. First made armillary sphere, and seismograph.' Stamp 2, indigo. Legend: 'Tsu Ch'ung-chih (A.D. 429-500). Mathematician. Computed 3.14159625 as the ratio of circumference of a circle to its diameter'" and "Stamp 3, black, Legend: 'Sun Yi-hsing (Chang Sui) (A.D. 683?-727). Astronomer. Computed 351.27 li as the sum of one degree of latitude.' Stamp 4, lake. Legend: 'Li Shih-chen (A.D. 1518-1593). Medical doctor and pharmacologist. Author of Pen Tsao Kang Mu, listing 1,892 kinds of medicinal substances.'" Below these clippings, Morgan has included originals of stamps 2, 3, and 4 described. Stamps 2 and 3 are clipped from the same envelope and have been stamped with a black 1955 Peking postage mark. Stamp 4 has been clipped from a different envelope, along with two other stamps, one depicting Stalin and Mao in the Kremlin and the other a red stamp depicting the Forbidden City. All three stamps have been marked with a black Peking postage mark from 1955. Morgan has also included a second group of three Chinese postage stamps, one from 25 June 1955 commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Chinese Red Cross, another copy of the red stamp of the Forbidden City, and an orange stamp also showing the Forbidden City. These three stamps are stamped with a 1955 black Peking postage mark. Morgan has also included a United Kingdom six pence postage stamp and a black The Duke of Edinburgh postage mark. Other images on this page include a black and white photograph of a man dressed in a white ribbed sweater standing outside and leaning on his knee in a posed manner, an original black and white photograph of a body of water and buildings along the waterfront on the far shore, a black and white photograph of a bat in mid-flight, three black and white clippings that likely came from the same source and are difficult to make out (may be clipped from an photograph of the ground?), an original photograph of a docked ship, a colour reproduction of a Chinese drawing of Confucius, a black and white photograph of a boy standing in front of Michelangelo's David statue, an original black and white photograph of a shirtless man with his arms raised in front of his face and bound with rope to a pole, a black and white photograph of a man squatting down in front of a piece of material, a black and white, full-length photograph of a man standing with his arms at his sides taken in profile, and a colour photograph of several men outside dancing in a circle in the desert, captioned as "Scène de danse magon, au Kalahari. (Cl. Balsan.)."

This page includes a large black and white photograph of Giacometti, in which two of his sculptures are visible in the background. Morgan has annotated the clipping with Giacometti's name in the upper right corner. Much of the rest of this page is themed around baths and water, with a black and white photograph of two men in a canoe reaching down to a third man who is swimming in the water, a black and white photograph of a crowd of people walking underneath a sign that reads "Baths" taken from above, an original black and white photograph of a naked man with a tattoo on his arm posing in the shower, a colour photograph of a spiral seashell, and a black and white photograph of Charlie Chaplin lying in a full bathtub while fully clothed and reading a newspaper. Three text-based clippings carry on this theme. The first is a paragraph which reads "Much of the woodwork of Longwood House was destroyed by white ants years ago, but the building has been repaired, and as a museum it will contain many things Napoleon used. For example, there is his bath, an antique affair with wooden sides. They told me Napoleon spent hours in it - he used to dictate his memoirs from it." The second is a short clipping, which reads "Trautmann, relaxing in his bath later, said, 'The Queen said to me, 'Well done!', and the Duke of Edinburgh asked me, 'What is the matter with you?''". The third is three clipped sections from O'Donnell's short story "'--House,' Near Blythswood Square, Glasgow. The Haunted Bath." The clippings recount the ghostly activity around the bath, including sloshing water and the sounds of someone bathing, despite no one being visible. The last of the three sections that Morgan has included from this story reads, "Then something, he would have given anything to tell what, came out and began to steal towards him". On the end of this sentence, Morgan has added a colon and then has pasted in two extra lines of text from different sources, the first reading "Bulorns, Kenacks ad Lizamoo" and the second reading "plumb bobs with sheathes, grains of paradise, gate frames for penstocks, oil foggers, or even dehydrated kibble." Other clippings on this page include a blue stamp from Egypt showing a crate on a hoist and the national emblem, a red stamp from China showing fireworks, a black and white photograph of a statue's eye, an original photograph of a naked man seated on the ground with someone's hand on his shoulder, four black and white clippings, all likely from the same source, that are decorative in nature and difficult to determine their subject, a black and white photograph of a man standing on a ship next to a sail with his back to the camera, and a black and white photograph captioned as "Plate 52 (detail from Plate 61). Ratha; projection on south face of Visnu Temple with recessed niche showing Visnu lying on the World Serpent 'Endless'. Deogarh, U.P., c. A.D. 500."
